The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: SECRET-LOVE, OR THE Maiden-Queen: As it is Acted By His Majesties Servants, AT THE THEATER-ROYAL.

q.l: â€”Vitiis nemo sine nascitur; optimus ille

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman, at the Sign of the Anchor, on the Lower-walk of the New-Exchange, 1668.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: IT has been the ordinary practice of the French Poets, to dedicate their Works of this nature to their King, especially when they have had the least encouragement to it, by his approbation of them on the Stage. But I confess I want the confidence to follow their example, though perhaps I have as specious pretences to it for this Piece, as any they can boast of: it having been own'd in so particular a manner by His Majesty, that he has grac'd it with the Title of His Play, and thereby rescued it from the severity (that I may not say malice) of its Enemies. But, though a character so high and undeserv'd, has not rais'd in me the presumption to offer such a trifle to his more serious view, yet I will own the vanity to say, that after this glory which it has receiv'd from a Soveraign Prince, I could not send it to seek protection from any Subject. Be this Poem then sacred to him without the tedious form of a Dedication, and without presuming to interrupt those hours which he is daily giving to the peace and settlement of his people.

For what else concerns this Play, I would tell the Reader that it is regular, according to the strictest of Dramatick Laws, but that it is a commendation which many of our Poets now despise, and a beauty which our common Audiences do not easily discern. Neither indeed do I value my self upon it, because with all that symmetry of parts, it may want an air and spirit (which consists in the writing) to set it off. 'Tis a question variously disputed, whether an Author may be allowed as a competent judg of his own works. As to the Fabrick and contrivance of them certainly he may, for that is properly the employment of the judgment; which, as a Master-builder may determine, and that without deception, whether the work be according to the exactness of the model; still granting him to have a perfect Idea of that pattern by which he works: and that he keeps himself always constant to the discourse of his judgment, without admitting self-love, which is the false surveigher of his Fancy, to intermeddle in it. These Qualifications granted (being such as all sound Poets are presupposed to have within them) I think all Writers, of what kind soever, may infallibly
judg of the frame and contexture of their Works. But for the ornament of Writing, which is greater, more various and bizarre in Poesie then in any other kind, as it is properly the Child of Fancy, so it can receive no measure, or at least but a very imperfect one of its own excellencies or faillures from the judgment. Self-love (which enters but rarely into the offices of the judgment) here predominates. And Fancy (if I may so speak) judging of it self, can be no more certain or demonstrative of its own effects, then two crooked lines can be the adaequate measure of each other. What I have said on this subject, may, perhaps, give me some credit with my Readers, in my opinion of this Play, which I have ever valued above the rest of my Follies of this kind: yet not thereby in the least dissenting from their judgment who have concluded the writing of this to be much inferior to my Indian Emperour. But the Argument of that was much more noble, not having the allay of Comedy to depress it: yet if this be more perfect, either in its kind, or in the general notion of a Play, 'tis as much as I desire to have granted for the vindication of my Opinion, and, what as nearly touches me, the sentence of a Royal Judg.
Many have imagin'd the Character of Philocles to be faulty; some for not discovering the Queens love, others for his joining in her restraint. But though I am not of their number, who obstinately defend what they have once said, I may with modesty take up those answers which have been made for me by my Friends; namely, that Philocles, who was but a Gentleman of ordinary birth, had no reason to guess so soon at the Queens Passion, she being a person so much above him, and by the suffrages of all her people, already destin'd to Lysimantes: Besides, that he was prepossessed, (as the Queen somewhere hints it to him) with another inclination which rendred him less clearsighted in it, since no man, at the same time, can distinctly view two different objects. And if this, with any shew of reason, may be defended, I leave my Masters the Criticks to determine whether it be not much more conducing to the beauty of my Plot, that Philocles should be long kept ignorant of the Queens love, then that with one leap he should have entred into the knowledg of it, and thereby freed himself, to the disgust of the Audience, from that pleasing Labyrinth of errors which was prepar'd for him. As for that other
objection of his joyning in the Queens imprisonment, it is indisputably that which every man, if he examines himself, would have done on the like occasion. If they answer that it takes from the height of his Character to do it; I would enquire of my over-wise Censors, who told them I intended him a perfect Character, or indeed what necessity was there he should be so, the variety of Images, being one great beauty of a Play? it was as much as I design'd, to show one great and absolute pattern of honour in my Poem, which I did in the Person of the Queen: All the defects of the other parts being set to show, the more to recommend that one character of Vertue to the Audience. But neigher was the fault of Philocles so great, if the circumstances be consider'd, which, as moral Philosophy assures us, make the essential differences of good and bad; He himself best explaining his own intentions in his last Act, which was the restauration of his Queen; and even before that, in the honesty of his expressions when he was unavoidably led by the impulsion of his love to do it. That which with more reason was objected as an indecorum, is the management of the last Scene of the Play, where Celadon
and Florimell are treating too lightly of their marriage in the presence of the Queen, who likewise seems to stand idle while the great action of the Drama is still depending. This I cannot otherwise defend, then by telling you I so design'd it on purpose to make my Play go off more smartly; that Scene, being in the opinion of the best judges, the most divertising of the whole Comedy. But though the Artifice succeeded, I am willing to acknowledg it as a fault, since it pleas'd His Majesty, the best Judg, to think it so. I have onely to add, that the Play is founded on a story in the Cyrus, which he calls the Queen of Corinth; in whose Character, as it has been affirm'd to me, he represents that of the famous Christina, Queen of Sweden. This is what I thought convenient to write by way of Preface, to the Maiden-Queen; in the reading of which, I fear you will not meet with that satisfaction which you have had in seeing it on the Stage; the chief parts of it both serious and comick, being performed to that height of excellence, that nothing but a command which I could not handsomely disobey, could have given me the courage to have made it publick.

div.head: Prologue.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: HE who writ this, not without pains and thought
From French and English Theaters has brought
Th' exactest Rules by which a Play is wrought.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The Unities of Action, Place, and Time;
The Scenes unbroken; and a mingled chime
Of Johnsons humour, with Corneilles rhyme.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: But while dead colours he with care did lay,
He fears his Wit, or Plot he did not weigh,
Which are the living Beauties of a Play.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Plays are like Towns, which howe're fortifi'd
By Engineers, have still some weaker side
By the o'reseen Defendant unespy'd.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: And with that Art you make approaches now;
Such skilful fury in Assaults you show,
That every Poet without shame may bow.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Ours therefore humbly would attend your doom,
If Souldier-like, he may have termes to come
With flying colours, and with beat of Drum.

div.p: The Prologue goes out, and stayes while a Tune is play'd, after which he returnes again.

lg.l: I Had forgot one half I do protest,
And now am sent again to speak the rest.
He bowes to every great and noble Wit,
But to the little Hectors of the Pit
Our Poet's sturdy, and will not submit.
He'll be before-hand with 'em, and not stay
To see each peevish Critick stab his Play:
Each Puny Censor, who his skill to boast,
Is cheaply witty on the Poets cost.
No Criticks verdict, should, of right, stand good,
They are excepted all as men of blood:
And the same Law should shield him from their fury
Which has exclud d Butchers from a Jury.
You'd all be Witsâ€”
But writing's tedious, and that way may fail;
The most compendious method is to rail:
Which you so like, you think your selves ill us'd
When in smart Prologues you are not abus'd.
A civil Prologue is approv'd by no man;
You hate it as you do a Civil woman:
Your Fancy's pall'd, and liberally you pay
To have it quicken'd, e're you see a Play.
Just as old Sinners worn from their delight,
Give money to be whip'd to appetite.
But what a Pox keep I so much ado
To save our Poet? he is one of you;
A Brother Judgment, and as I hear say,
A cursed Critick as e're damn'd a Play.
Good salvage Gentlemen your own kind spare,
He is, like you, a very Wolf, or Bear;
Yet think not he'll your ancient rights invade,
Or stop the course of your free damning trade:
For he, (he vows) at no friends Play can sit
But he must needs find fault to shew his Wit:
Then, for his sake, ne're stint your own delight;
Throw boldly, for he sets to all that write;
With such he ventures on an even lay,
For they bring ready money into Play.
Those who write not, and yet all Writers nick,
Are Bankrupt Gamesters, for they damn on Tick.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAge 11. lin. 21. dele you are. Pag. 17. lin. 3. dele more. Pag. 18. lin. 8. for from read on. Ibid. lin. 27. for to read so. Pag. 22. lin. 26. read from me. Pag. 28. for sweats read sweets. Pag. 33. lin. penult, for invites read invite. Pag. 42 lin. 11. for secur'd read secure. Pag. 44. from Annalls, read from the Annals. Pag. 49. lin. 5. for or read on.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene is Walks, near the Court.
Enter Celadon, Asteria, meeting each other: he in riding habit; they embrace.

sp.speaker: Celedon.
sp.p: DEar Asteria!

sp.speaker: Asteria.
sp.p: My dear Brother! welcome; a thousand welcomes: Me thinks this year you have been absent has been so tedious! I hope as you have made a pleasant Voyage, so you have brought your good humour back again to Court.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I never yet knew any Company I could not be merry in, except it were an old Womans.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Or at a Funeral;

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Nay, for that you shall excuse me; for I was never merrier then I was at a Creditors of mine, whose Book perished with him. But what new Beauties have you at Court? How do Melissa's two fair Daughters?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: When you tell me which of 'em you are in love with, I'le answer you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Which of 'em, naughty sister, what a question's there? With both of 'em, with each and singular of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Bless me! you are not serious!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: You look as if it were a wonder to see a man in love: are they not handsome?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I, but both togetherâ€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I, and both asunder; why, I hope there are but two of 'em, the tall Singing and Dancing one, and the little Innocent one?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: But you cannot marry both?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No, nor either of 'em I trust in Heaven; but I can keep them company, I can sing and dance with 'em, and treat 'em, and that, I take it, is somewhat better then musty marrying them: Marriage is poor folks pleasure that cannot go to the cost of variety: but I am out of danger of that with these two, for I love 'em so equally I can never make choice between 'em: Had I but one mistress, I might go to her to be merry, and she, perhaps, be out of humour; there were a visit lost: But here, if one of 'em frown upon me, the other will be the more obliging, on purpose to recommend her own gayety, besides a thousand things that I could name.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: And none of 'em to any purpose.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Well, if you will not be cruel to a poor Lover, you might oblige me by carrying me to their lodgings.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You know I am always busie about the Queen.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: But once or twice onely, till I am a little flush'd in my acquaintance with other Ladies, and have learn'd to prey for my self: I promise you I'le make all the haste I can to end your trouble, by being in love somewhere else.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You would think it hard to be deny'd now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And reason good: many a man hangs himself for the loss of one Mistris; How do you think then I should bear the loss of two; especially in a Court where I think Beauty is but thin sown.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: There's one Florimell the Queen's Ward, a new Beauty, as wilde as you, and a vast Fortune.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I am for her before the world: bring me to her, and I'le release you of your promise for the other two.
Madam, the Queen expects you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I see you hold her favour; Adieu Sister, you have a little Emissary there, otherwise I would offer you my service.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Farwel Brother, think upon Florimell.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
You may trust my memory for an handsome woman,
I'le think upon her, and the rest too; I'le forget none of 'em.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter a Gentleman walking over the Stage hastily: after him, Florimel, and Flavia Masqued.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Phormio, Phormio, you will not leave usâ€”

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: In faith I have a little businessâ€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Cannot I serve you in the Gentlemans room, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Which of us would you serve?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Either of you, or both of you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Why, could you not be constant to one?

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.p: Constant to one! I have been a Courtier, a Souldier, and a Traveller, to good purpose, if I must be constant to one; give me some Twenty, some Forty, some a Hundred Mistresses, I have more Love than any one woman can turn her to.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Bless us, let us be gone Cousin; we two are nothing in his hands.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Yet for my part, I can live with as few Mistresses as any man: I desire no superfluities; onely for necessary change or so; as I shift my Linnen.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Apretty odd kind of fellow this: he fits my humour rarely:â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: You are as unconstant as the Moon:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You wrong him, he's as constant as the Sun; he would see all the world round in 24 hours.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Madam, but, like him, I would visit and away.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: For what an unreasonable thing it were to stay long, be troublesome, and hinder a Lady of a fresh Lover.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: A rare Creature this!â€”besides Madam, how like a fool a man looks, when after all his eagerness of two Minutes before, he shrinks into a faint kiss and a cold complement.
Ladies both, into your hands I commit my selfe; share me betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I'll have nothing to do with you, since you cannot be constant to one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Nay, rather then loose either of you, I'll do more; I'll be constant to an 100 of you: or, (if you will needs fetter me to one,) agree the matter between your selves; and the most handsome take me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Though I am not she, yet since my Masque's down, and you cannot convince me, have a good faith of my Beauty, and for once I take you for my servant.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: And for once, I'll make a blind bargain with you: strike hands; is't a Match Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Done Servant:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Now I am sure I have the worst on't: for you see the worst of me, and that I do not of you till you shew your face:â€”
Yet now I think on't, you must be handsome.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What kind of Beauty do you like?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Just such a one as yours.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Such an Ovall face, clear skin, hazle eyes, thick brown Eyebrowes, and Hair as you have for all the world.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: But I can â€¢ ssure you she has nothing of all this.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Hold thy peace Envy; nay I can be constant an'I set on't.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Tis true she tells you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I, I, you may slander your self as you please; then you have,â€”let me see.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I'll swear you shan'not see.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: A turn'd up Nose: that gives an air to your face: Oh, I find I am more and more in love with you! a full neather-lip, an outmouth, that makes mine water at it: the bottom of your cheeks a little blub, and two dimples when you smile: for your stature 'tis well, and for your wit 'twas given you by one that knew it had been thrown away upon an ill face; come you are handsome, there's no denying it:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Can you settle your spirits to see an ugly face, and not be frighted, I could find in my heart to lift up my Masque and disabuse you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I defie your Masque, would you would try the experiment:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: No, I won'not; for your ignorance is the Mother of your devotion to me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Since you will not take the pains to convert me I'll make bold
to keep my faith: a miserable man I am sure you have made me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: This is pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: It may be so to you but it is not to me; for ought I see, I am going to be the most constant Maudlin.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Celadon, you can be constant to one you have never seen; and have forsaken all you have seen.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: It seems you know me then: well, if thou shou'dst prove one of my cast Mistresses I would use thee most damnably, for offering to make me love thee twice.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You are i'th' right: an old Mistriss or Servant is an old Tune, the pleasure on't is past, when we have once learnt it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: But what woman in the world would you wish her like?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I have heard of one Florimel the Queens Ward, would she were as like her for Beauty, as she is for Humour.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Do you hear that Cousin:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Florimell's not handsome: besides she's unconstant; and only loves for some few days,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: If she loves for shorter time then I, she must love by Winter daies and Summer nights ifaith:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: When you see us together you shall judge: in the mean time adieu sweet servant.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Why you won' not be so inhumane to carry away my heart and not so much as tell me where I may hear news on't?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I mean to keep it safe for you; for if you had it, you would bestow it worse: farwell, I must see a Lady:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: So must I too, if I can pull off your Masqueâ€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You will not be so rude, I hope;

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: By this light but I will:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: By this leg but you shan not:

div.head: SCENE. III.
div.stage: Enter Philocles, and meets him going out.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: How! my Cousin the new Favourite!â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dear Celadon! most happily arriv'd.
I hear y'have been an honour to your Country
In the Calabrian Wars, and I am glad
I have some interest in't.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: â€”â€”â€”â€”But in you
I have a larger subject for my joyes:
To see so rare a thing as rising vertue,
And merit understood at Court.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Perhaps it is the onely act that can
Accuse our Queen of weakness.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: O, my Lord Philocles, well overtaken!
I came to look you (Phil.) had I known it sooner
My swift attendance, Sir, had spar'd your trouble.
To Cel.â€”Cousin, you see Prince Lysimantes
Is pleased to favour me with his Commands:
I beg you'l be no stranger now at Court.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So long as there be Ladies there, you need
Not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Some of them will, I hope, make you a Convert.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: My Lord Philocles, I am glad we are alone;
There is a busines that concerns me nearly,
In which I beg your love. (Phil.) Command my service.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I know your Interest with the Queen is great;
(I speak not this as envying your fortune,
For frankly I confess you have deserv'd it.)
Besides, my Birth, my Courage, and my Honour,
Are all above so base a Viceâ€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I know, my Lord, you are first Prince o'th' Blood;
Your Countries second hope;
And that the publick Vote, when the Queen weds,
Designes you for her choice.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I am not worthy.
Except Love makes desert;
For doubtless she's the glory of her time;
Of faultless Beauty, blooming as the Spring,
In our Sicilian Groves; matchless in Vertue,
And largely sould, where ere her bounty gives,
As with each breath she could create new Indies.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But jealous of her glory.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You are a Courtier; and in other terms,
Would say she is averse from marriage
Least it might lesson her authority.
But, whensoe're she does, I know the people
Will scarcely suffer her to match
With any neighb'ring Prince, whose power might bend
Our free Sicilians to a foreign Yoke.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I love too well my Country to desire it.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Then to proceed, (as you well know, my Lord)
The Provinces have sent their Deputies
Humbly to move her she would choose at home:
And, for she seems averse from speaking with them,
By my appointment, have design'd these walks,
Where well she cannot shun them. Now, if you
Assist their suit, by joyning yours to it,
And by your mediation I prove happy,
I freely promise you.â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Without a Bribe command my utmost in it:â€”
And yet, there is a thing, which time may give me
The confidence to name:â€”(Lys.) 'Tis yours whatever.
But tell me true; does she not entertain
Some deep, and setled thoughts against my person?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I hope not so; but she, of late, is froward;
Reserv'd, and sad, and vex'd at little things;
Which, her great soul asham'd of, straight shakes off,
And is compos'd again.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You are still near the Queen, and all our Actions come to
Princes eyes, as they are represented by them that hold the mirour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here she comes, and with her the Deputies;â€”
I fear all is not right,
sp.stage: Enter Queen; Deputies after her; Asteria, Guard, Flavia, Olinda, Sabina.
Queen turns back to the Deputies, and speaks entring.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And I must tell you,
It is a sawcy boldness thus to press
On my retirements.â€”

sp.speaker: 1. Dep.
sp.l: Our business being of no less concern
Then is the peace and quiet of your Subjectsâ€”and that delay'dâ€”

sp.speaker: 2. Dep.
sp.l: â€”â€”â€”â€”we humbly took this time
To represent your peoples fears to you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My peoples fears! who made them States-men?
They much mistake their business, if they think
It is to govern:
The Rights of Subjects and of Soveraigns
Are things distinct in Nature: theirs, is to
Enjoy Propriety, not Empire.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: If they have err'd, 'twas but an over-care;
An ill-tim'd Duty.â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Cousin, I expect
From your near Bloud, not to excuse, but check 'em.
They would impose a Ruler
Upon their Lawful Queen:
For what's an Husband else;

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Fair; Madam, be it from the thoughts
Of any who pretends to that high Honour,
To with for more then to be reckon'd
As the most grac'd, and first of all your servants.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: These are th'insinuating promises
Of those who aim at pow r: but tell me Cousin;
(For you are unconcern'd and may be Judge)
Should that aspiring man compass his ends,
What pawn of his obedience could he give me,
When Kingly pow'r were once invested in him?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: What greater pledge then Love? when those fair eyes,
Cast their commanding beams, he that cou'd be
A Rebel to your birth, must pay them homage.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: All eyes are fair
That sparkle with the Jewels of a Crown:
Put now I see my Government is odious;
My people find I am not fit to Reign,
â€¢ se they would neverâ€”â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: So far from that, we all acknowledge you
The bounty of the Gods to Sicilie:
More than they are you cannot make our Joyes;
Make them but lasting in a Successor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your people seek not to impose a Prince;
But humbly offer one to your free chioce:
And such an one he is, (may I have leave
To speak some little of his great deserts.)

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'le hear no moreâ€”

sp.speaker: To the Dep.
sp.l: For you, attend tomorrow at the Council,
There you shall have my firm resolves; mean time
My Cousin I am sure will welcome you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Still more and more mysterious: but I have gain'd one of her women that shall unriddle it:â€”Come Gentlemen.â€”

sp.speaker: All Dep.
sp.l: Heav'n preserve your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Philocles you may stay:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I humbly wait your Majesties commands.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yet, now I better think on't, you may go.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have no commands.â€”or, what's all one
You no obedience.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How, no obedience, Madam?
I plead no other merit; 'tis the Charter
By which I hold your favour, and my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My favours are cheap blessings, like Rain and Sun-shine,
For which we scarcely thank the Gods, because we daily have them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, your Breath which rais'd me from the dust
May lay me there again
But fate nor time can ever make me loose
The sense of your indulgent bounties to me

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You are above them now; grown popular:
Ah Philocles, could I expect from you
That usage I have found! no tongue but yours
To move me to a marriage?â€”
The factious Deputies might have some end in't,
And my ambitious Cousin gain a Crown;
But what advantage could there come to you?
What could you hope from Lysimantes Reign
That you can want in mine?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You your self clear me, Madam, had I sought
More pow'r, this Marriage sure was not the way.
But, when your safety was in question.
When all your people were unsatisfied,
Desir'd a King, nay more, design'd the Man,
It was my duty then.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Let me be judge of my own safety;
I am a woman,
But danger from my Subjects cannot fright me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But Lysimantes, Madam, is a personâ€”â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I cannot love,â€”â€”
Shall I, I who am born a Sovereign Queen,
Be barr'd of that which God and Nature gives
The meanest Slave, a freedom in my love?
â€”Leave me, good Philocles, to my own thoughts;
When next I need your counsel I'le send for youâ€”

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: I'm most unhappy in your high displeasure;
But, since I must not speak, Madam, be pleas'd
To peruse this, and therein, read my care:
sp.stage: He plucks out a paper, and presents it to her. But drops, unknown to him a picture;

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: reads.â€”
A Catalogue of such personsâ€”

sp.speaker: Spies the box.
sp.l: What's this he has let fall? Asteria?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Your Majestyâ€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Take that up, it fell from Philocles.
sp.stage: She takes it up, looks on it, and smiles.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How now, what makes you merry?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: A small discovery I have made, Madam;

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Since first your Majesty grac'd Philocles,
I have not heard him nam'd for any Mistriss
But now this picture has convinc'd me.â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha! Let me see it
Candiope, Prince Lysimantes sister!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Your favour, Madam, may encourage himâ€”
And yet he loves in a high place for him:
A Princess of the Blood, and what is more,
Beyond comparison the fairest Lady
Our Isle can boast.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How! she the fairest
Beyond comparison? 'tis false, you flatter her;
She is not fair.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I humbly beg forgiveness on my knees,
If I offended you: But next yours, Madam,
Which all must yield toâ€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I pretend to none

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: She passes for a beauty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I, She may pass.â€”But why do I speak of her?
Dear Asteria lead me, I am not well o'th sudden.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Who's near there? help the Queen.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Bid 'em away, 'twas but a qualm,
And 'tis already going.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Dear Madam what's the matter! y'are
You are of late so alter'd I scarce know you.
You were gay humour'd, and you now are pensive,
Once calm, and now unquiet;
Pardon my boldness that I press thus far
Into your secret thoughts: I have at least
A subjects share in you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou hast a greater,
That of a friend; but am I forward, saist thou!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: It ill becomes me, Madam, to say that.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I know I am: prithee forgive me for it.
I cannot help it, but thou hast
Not long to suffer it.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I feel my strength insensibly consume,
Like Lillies wasting in a Lymbecks heat.
Yet a few dayesâ€”
And thou shalt see me lie all damp and cold,
Shrowded within some hollow Vault, among
My silent Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: O dearest Madam!
Speak not of death, or think not, if you die
That I will stay behind.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thy love has mov'd me, I for once will have
The pleasure to be pitied; I le unfold
A thing so strange, so horrid of my self;â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Bless me, sweet Heaven!
So horrid, said you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: That Sun, who with one look surveys the Globe,
Sees not a wretch like me: and could the world
Take a right measure of my state within,
Mankind must either pity me, or scorn me.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Sure none could do the last.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou long'st to know it:
And I to tell thee, but shame stops my mouth.
First promise me thou wilt excuse my folly,
And next be secret.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: â€”â€”â€”Can you doubt it Madam!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yet you might spare my labour;
Can you not guessâ€”.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Madam, please you, I'le try.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hold: Asteria:
I would not have you guess, for should you find it
I should imagine, that some other might,
And then, I were most wretched.
Therefore, though you should know it, flatter me:
And say you could not guess it.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Madam, I need not flatter you, I cannot.â€”and yet,
Might not Ambition trouble your repose?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Sicily I thank the Gods, contents me.
But since I must reveal it, know 'tis love:
I who pretended so to glory, am
Become the slave of love.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I thought your Majesty had fram'd designes
To subvert all your Laws; become a Tyrant,
Or vex your neighbours with injurious wars;
Is this all? Madam?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is not this enough?
Then, know, I love below my self; a Subject;
Love one who loves another, and who knows not
That I love him.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: He must be told it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not for the world: Asteria:
When ere he knows it I shall die for shame.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: What is it then that would content you?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nothing, but that I had not lov'd?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: May I not ask without offence who 'tis?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ev'n that confirms me I have lov'd amiss;
Since thou canst know I love, and not imagine
It must be Philocles

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: My Cousin is indeed a most deserving person;
Valiant and wise; and handsome; and well born,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But not of Royal bloud:
I know his fate unfit to be a King.
To be his wife I could forsake my Crown; but not my glory:
Yet,â€”would he did not love Candiope;
Would he lov'd me,â€”but knew not of my love,
Or ere durst tell me his: Ast. In all this Labyrinth,
I find one path conducing to your quiet,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O tell me quickly then.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Candiope, as Princess of the Bloud
Without your approbation cannot marry:
First break his match with her, by vertue of
Your Sovereign Authority.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I fear. That were to make him hate me.
Or, what's as bad, to let him know I love him:
Could you not do it of your self?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Ile not be wanting to my pow'r
But if your Majesty appears not in it
The love of Philocles will soon surmount
All other difficulties.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then, as we walk, we'l think what means are best
Effect but this, and thou shar'st halfe my breast.

sp.speaker: Asteria,
sp.l: NOthing thrives that I have plotted:

sp.speaker: Sola.
sp.l: For I have sounded Philocles, and find
He is too constant to Candiope
Her too I have assaulted, but in vain,
Objecting want of quality in Philocles.
I'le to the Queen, and plainly tell her
She must make use of her Authority
To break the match.
Brother! what make you here
About the Queens appartments?
Which of the Ladies are you watching for?

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.p: Any of 'em that will do me the good turn to make me soundly in love.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Then I'le bespeak you one; you will be desp'rately in love with Florimel: so soon as the Queen heard you were return'd she gave you her for Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Thank her Majesty; but to confess the truth my fancy lies partly another way.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: That's strange: Florimel vows you are already in love with her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: She wrongs me horribly, if ever I saw or spoke with this Florimel.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Well, take your fortune, I must leave you.

div.head: SCENE, III.
div.stage: Enter Florimel, sees him, and is running back.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Nay 'faith I am got betwixt you and home, you are my pris'ner, Lady bright, till you resolve me one question.

sp.speaker: She signs.
sp.p: She is dumb. Pox; I think she's dumb: what a vengeance dost thou at Court, with such a rare face, without a tongue to answer to a kind question. Art thou dumb indeed, then, thou canst tell no tales,â€”goes to kiss her.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Hold, hold, you are not mad!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Oh, my miss in a Masque! have you found your tongue?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'T was time, I think; what had become of me, if I had not?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Methinks your lips had done as well.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I, if my Masque had been over 'em, as it was when you met me in the walks.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Well; will you believe me another time? did not I say you were infinitely handsome: they may talk of Florimel, if they will, but i'faith she must come short of you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Have you seen her, then?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I look'd a little that way, but I had soon enough of her, she is not to be seen twice without a surfeit.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: However you are beholding to her, they say she loves you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: By fate she shan'not love me: I have told her a piece of my mind already: pox o'these coming women: they set a man to dinner before he has an appetite.

sp.speaker: Florimel
sp.p: you are call'd within.â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I hope in the Lord you are not Florimel;

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Ev'n she at your service; the same kind and coming Florimel you have describ'd:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Why then we are agreed already, I am as kind and coming as you for the heart of you: I knew at first we two were good for nothing but one another.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But, without raillery, are you in Love?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: So horribly much, that contrary to my own Maxims, I think in my conscience I could marry you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis not come to that yet: but if you are really in love you have done me the greatest pleasure in the world.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: That pleasure, and a better too I have in store for you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: This Animal call'd a Lover I have long'd to see these two years.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Sure you walk'd with your mask on all the while, for if you had been seen, you could not have been without your wish.

sp.speaker: Flor
sp.p: I warrant you mean an ordinary whining Lover; but I must have other proofs of love ere I believe it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: You shall have the best that I can give you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I would have a Lover, that if need be, should hang himself, drown himself, break his neck, or poyson himself for very despair: he that will scruple this is an impudent fellow if he sayes he is in love.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, which of these four things would you have your Lover do? for a man's but a man, he cannot hang, and drown, and break his neck, and poyson himself, altogether.

sp.speaker: Flor,
sp.p: Well then, because you are but a beginner, and I would not discourage you, any one of these shall serve your turn in a fair way.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I am much deceiv'd in those eyes of yours, if a Treat, a Song, and the Fiddles, be not a more acceptable proof of love to you, then any of those Tragical ones you have mentioned.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: However you will grant it is but decent you should be pale, and lean, and melancholick to shew you are in love: and that I shall require of you when I see you next.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: When you see me next? why you do not make a Rabbet of me, to be lean at 24 hours warning? in the mean while we burn daylight, loose time and love.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Would you marry me without consideration?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: To choose, by heaven, for they that think on't, twenty to one would never do it, hang forecast; to make sure of one, good night is as much in reason as a man should expect from this ill world.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Methinks a few more years and discretion would do well: I do not like this going to bed so early; it makes one so weary before morning.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: That's much as your pillow is laid before you go to sleep.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Shall I make a proposition to you? I will give you a whole year of probation to love me in; to grow reserv'd, discreet, sober and faithful, and to pay me all the services of a Lover.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And at the end of it you'll marry me?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: If neither of us alter our minds before.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: By this light a necessary clause.â€”but if I pay in all the foresaid services before the day, you shall be obliged to take me sooner into mercy.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Provided if you prove unfaithful, then your time of a Twelvemonth to be prolong'd; so many services I will bate you so many dayes or weeks; so many faults I will add more to your 'Prentiship, so much more: And of all this I onely to be Judg.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Is the Queen this way, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I'le see, so please your Highness: Follow me, Captive.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: March on Conquerourâ€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You're sure her Majesty will not oppose it?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leave that to me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Then, though perhaps my Sisters birth might challenge
An higher match,
I'le weigh your merits on the other side
To make the ballance even

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I go my Lord this minute.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: My best wishes wait on you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yonder he is; have I no other way?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: O Madam, you must stand this brunt:
Deny him now, and leave the rest to me:
I'le to Candiope's Mother,
And under the pretence of friendship, work
On her Ambition to put off a match
So mean as Philocles.

sp.speaker: [Qu. to Phil.]
sp.l: You may approach, Sir,
We two discourse no secrets.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I come, Madam, to weary out your royal bounty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Some suit I warrant for your Cousin Celadon.
Leave his advancement to my care.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your goodness still prevents my wishes:â€”yet I have one request
Might it not pass almost for madness, and
Extream Ambition in me.â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You know you have a favourable Judg,
It lies in you not to ask any thing
I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, perhaps you think me now too faulty:
But Love alone inspires me with ambition,
Though but to look from fair Candiope, were an excuse for both.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Keep your Ambition, and let Love alone;
That I can cloy, but this I cannot cure.
I have some reasons (invincible to me) which must forbid
Your marriage with Candiope.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I knew I was not worthy.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not for that, Philocles, you deserve all things,
And to show I think it, my Admiral I hear is dead
His vacant place (the best in all my Kingdom,)
I here confer on you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Rather take back all you have giv'n before,
Then not give this.
For believe; Madam, nothing is so near
My soul, as the possession of Candiope.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Since that belief would be your disadvantage,
I will not entertain it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, Madam, can you be thus cruel to me?
To give me all things which I did not ask,
And yet deny that onely thing I beg:
And to beg that I find I cannot live
Without the hope of it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hope greater things;
But hope not this. Haste to o'recome your love,
It is but putting a short liv'd passion to a violent death.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I cannot live without Candiope.
But I can die without a murmure,
Having my doom pronounced from your fair mouth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: If I am to pronounce it, live my Philocles,
But live without (I was about to say
Without his love, but that I cannot do)
Live Philocles without Candiope.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ah, Madam, could you give my doom so quickly
And knew it was irrevocable!
'Tis too apparent
You who alone love glory, and whose soul
Is loosned from your senses, cannot judg
What torments mine, of grosser mould, endures.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I cannot suffer you
To give me praises which are not my own:
I love like you, and am yet much more wretched
Then you can think your self.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Weak barrs they needs must be that fortune puts
'Twixt Soveraign Power, and all it can desire.
When Princes love, they call themselves unhappy,
Onely because the word sounds handsome in a Lovers mouth.
But you can cease to be so when you please
By making Lysimantes fortunate.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Were he indeed the man, you had some reason;
But 'tis another, more without my power,
And yet a subject too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O, Madam, say not so,
It cannot be a Subject if not he.
It were to be injurious to your self
To make another choice.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yet Lysimantes, set by him I love,
Is more obscur'd then Stars too near the Sun;
He has a brightness of his own,
Not borrow'd of his Fathers, but born with him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon me if I say, who'ere he be,
He has practis'd some ill Acts upon you, Madam;
For he, whom you describe, I see is born but from the lees o'th people.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You offend me Philocles.
Whence had you leave to use those insolent terms
Of him I please to love: one I must tell you,
(Since foolishly I have gone on thus far)
Whom I esteem your equal,
And far superiour to Prince Lysimantes;
One who deserves to wear a Crown.â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Whirl winds bear me hence before I live
To that detested day.â€”That frown assures me
I have offended, by my over freedom;
But yet me thinks a heart so plain and honest
And zealous of your glory, might hope your pardon for it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I give it you; but
When you know him better
You'l alter your opinion; he's no ill friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I well perceive
He has supplanted me in your esteem;
But that's the least of ills this fatal wretch
Has practis'd.â€”Think, for Heavens sake, Madam, think
If you have drunk no Phylter.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes he has given me a Phylter;â€”
But I have drunk it onely from his eyes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hot Irons thank 'em for't.â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What's that you mutter?
Hence from my sight: I know not whether
I ever shall endure to see you more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: â€”But hear me, Madam:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I say be gone.â€”See me no more this day.â€”
I will not hear one word in your excuse:
Now, Sir, be rude again; And give Laws to your Queen.
Asteria, come hither.
Was ever boldness like to this of Philocles?
Help me to reproach him; for I resolve
Henceforth no more to love him.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Truth is, I wondred at your patience, Madam:
Did you not mark his words, his meen, his action,
How full of haughtiness, how small respect?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And he to use me thus, he whom I favour'd,
Nay more, he whom I lov'd?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: A man, me thinks, of vulgar parts and presence!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Or allow him something handsome, valiant, or soâ€”
Yet this to me!â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: The workmanship of inconsiderate favour,
The Creature of rash love; one of those Meteors
Which Monarchs raise from earth,
And people wondring how they came so high,
Fear, from their influence, Plagues, and Wars, and Famine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: One whom instead of banishing a day,
You should have plum'd of all his borrow'd honours:
And let him see what abject things they are
Whom Princes often love without desert.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What has my Philocles deserv'd from thee
That thou shouldst use him thus?
Were he the basest of Mankind thou could'st not
Have given him ruder language.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Did not your Majesty command me,
Did not your self begin?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I grant I did, but I have right to do it;
I love him, and may rail;â€”in you 'tis malice;
Malice in the most high degree; for never man
Was more deserving then my Philocles.
Or, do you love him, ha! and plead that title?
Confess, and I'le forgive you.â€”
For none can look on him but needs must love.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I love him, Madam! I beseech your Majesty
Have better thoughts of me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Dost thou not love him then!
Good Heav'n, how stupid and how dull is she!
How most invincibly insensible!
No woman does deserve to live
That loves not Philocles.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Dear madam, recollect your self; alas
How much distracted are your thoughts, and how
Dis-jointed all your words;â€”
The Sybills leaves more orderly were laid.
Where is that harmony of mind, that prudence
Which guided all you did! that sense of glory
Which rais'd you, high above the rest of Kings
As Kings are o're the level of mankind!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Gone, gone Asteria, all is gone,
Or lost within me far from any use.
Sometimes I struggle like the Sun in Clouds,
But straight I am o'recast.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I grieve to see it.â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then thou hast yet the goodness
To pardon what I said.â€”
Alas, I use my self much worse then thee.
Love rages in great souls,â€”
For there his pow'r most opposition finds;
High trees are shook, because they dare the winds.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE of the Act, The Court Gallery.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'TIs true, she banish'd me but for a day;
But Favourites, once declining, sink apace.
Yet Fortune, stop,â€”this is the likeliest place
To meet Asteria, and by her convey,
My humble vows to my offended Queen.
Ha! She comes her self; Unhappy man
Where shall I hide?â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is not that Philocles who makes such haste away? Philocles, Philoclesâ€”
sp.stage: [Philocles coming back, [I fear'd she saw me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How now Sir, am I such a Bugbear
That I scare people from?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I should more carefully have shun'd
The place where you might be; as, when it thunders
Men reverently quit the open Air
Because the angry Gods are then abroad.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What does he mean, Asteria?
I do not understand him.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Your Majesty forgets you banish'd him,
Your presence for this day.â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha! banish'd him! 'tis true indeed;
But, as thou sayst, I had forgot it quite.â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: That's very strange, scarce half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But Love had drawn his pardon up so soon
That I forgot he e're offended me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon me, that I could not thank you sooner:
Your sudden grace, like some swift flood pour'd in on narrow bancks
O'reflow'd my spirits.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No; 'tis for me to aske your pardon Philocles,
For the great injury I did you
In not remembring I was angry with you.
But I'le repair my fault,
And rowze my anger up against you yet:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, Madam, my forgiveness was your Act of grace
And I lay hold of it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Princes sometimes may pass,
Acts of Oblivion in their own wrong:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis true; but not recall them.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But, Philocles, since I have told you there is one I love.
I will go on; and let you know
What passed this day betwixt us; be you judg
Whether my servant have dealt well with me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I beseech your Majesty excuse me:
Any thing more of him may make me
Relapse too soon, and forfeit my late pardon.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But you'l be glad to know it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: May I not hope then
You have some quarrel to him?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, a great one.
But first, to justifie my self
Know, Philocles, I have conceal'd my passion
With such care from him, that he knows not yet
I love, but onely that I much esteem him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O stupid wretch
That by a thousand tokens could not guess it!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He loves elsewhere, and that has blinded him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He's blind indeed!
So the dull Beasts in the first Paradise
With levell'd eyes gaz'd each upon their kind;
There fix'd their love: and ne're look'd up to view
That glorious Creature man, their soveraign Lord.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Y'are too severe, on little faults, but he has crimes, untold,
Which will, I fear, move you much more against him.
He fell this day into a passion with me,
And boldly contradicted all I sed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And stands his head upon his Shoulders yet?
How long shall this most insolentâ€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Take heed you rail not,
You know you are but on your good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why then I will not call him Traytorâ€”
But onely rude, audacious and impertinent,
To use his Soveraign so.â€”I beg your leave
To wish you have, at least imprison'd him

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Some people may speak ill, and yet mean well:
Remember you were not confin'd; and yet
Your fault was great. In short, I love him
And that excuses all; but be not jealous;
His rising shall not be your overthrow,
Nor wil! I ever marry him.â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That's some comfort yet
He shall not be a King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He never shall. But you are discompos'd;
Stay here a little; I have somewhat for you
Shall shew you still are in my favour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now, in tears, my fair Candiope?
So through a watry Clowd
The Sun at once seems both to weep and shine.
For what Forefathers sin do you afflict
Those precious eyes? for sure you have
None of your own to weep.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: My Crimes both great and many needs must show
Since Heav'n will punish them with loosing you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Afflictions sent from Heav'n without a cause
Make bold Mankind enquire into its Laws.
But Heav'n, which moulding beauty takes such care
Makes gentle fates on purpose for the fair:
And destiny that sees them so divine,
Spinn's all their fortunes in a silken twine:
No mortal hand so ignorant is found
To weave course work upon a precious ground.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Go preach this doctrine in my Mother's ears.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Has her severity produc'd these tears:

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: She has recall'd those hopes she gave before,
And strictly bids me ne're to see you more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Changes in froward age are Natural;
Who hopes for constant weather in the fall?
'Tis in your pow'r your duty to transfer
And place that right in me which was in her.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Reason, like foreign foes, would ne're o'recome,
But that I find I am betray'd at home.
You have a friend that fights for you within:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let Reason ever lose, so love may win.
sp.stage: Queen with a Picture in her hand.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: See there, Asteria,
All we have done succeeds still to the worse;
We hindred him from seeing her at home,
Where I but onely heard they lov'd; and now
She comes to Court, and mads me with the sight on't.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Dear Madam. overcome your self a little,
Or they'l perceive how much you are concern'd.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I struggle with my heart,â€”but it will have some vent.
Cousin, you are a stranger at the Court.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: It was my duty I confess,
To attend oftner on your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Asteria, Mend my Cousins Handkerchief;
It sits too narrow there, and shows too much
The broadness of her Shoulders.â€”Nay fie, Asteria,
Now you put it too much backward, and discover
The bigness of her breasts.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I beseech your Majesty
Give not your self this trouble,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sweet Cousin, you shall pardon me;
A beauty such as yours
Deserves a more then ordinary care,
To set it out.
Come hither, Philocles, do but observe,
She has but one gross fault in all her shape,
That is, she bears up here too much,
And the malicious Workman has left it open to your eye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where, and 'please your Majesty, methinks 'tis very well?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Do not you see it, Oh how blind is love!

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: And how quick-sighted malice!â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But yet methinks, those knots of sky, do not
So well with the dead colour of her face.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Your Majesty mistakes, she wants no red.
sp.stage: The Queen here plucks out her Glass, and looks sometimes on her self, sometimes on her Rival.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How do I look to day, Asteria!
Methinks not well.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Pardon me, Madam, most victoriously.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What think you, Philocles? come do not flatter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Paris was a bold man who presum'd
To judg the beauty of a Goddess.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Your Majesty has given the reason why
He cannot judge; his Love has blinded him:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Methinks a long patch here beneath her eye
Might hide that dismal hallowness, what think you Philocles?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Beseech you Madam, aske not his opinion;
What my faults are it is no matter;
He loves me with them all.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I, he may love, but when he marries you
Your Bridal shall be kept in some dark Dungeon.
Farwel, and think of that, too easie Maid,
I blush, thou shar'st my bloud.â€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: In humane Queen!
Thou canst not be more willing to resign
Thy part in me, then I to give up mine:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Love, how few Subjects do thy Laws fulfil,
And yet those few, like us, thou usest ill!

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The greatest slaves, in Monarchies, are they,
Whom Birth sets nearest to Imperial sway.
While jealous pow'r does sullenly o're spy,
We play like Deer within the Lions eye.
Would I for you some Shepherdess had been;
And, but each May, ne're heard the name of Queen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If you were so, might I some Monarch be,
Then, you should gain what now you loose by me:
Then, you in all my glories should have part,
And rule my Empire, as you rule my heart.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: How much our golden wishes are in vain?
When they are past we are our selves again.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Look, look Asteria, yet they are not gone.
Hence, we may hear what they discourse alone.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My Love inspires me with a gen'rous thought
Which you unknowing, in those wishes taught.
Since happiness may out of Courts be found
Why stay we here on this enchanted ground?
And choose not rather with content to dwell
(If Love and we can find it) in a Cell?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Those who, like you, have once in Courts been great,
May think they wish, but wish not to retreat.
They seldom go but when they cannot stay;
As loosing Gamesters throw the Dice away:
Ev'n in that Cell, where you repose would find,
Visions of Court will haunt your restless mind;
And glorious dreams stand ready to restore
The pleasing shapes of all you had before.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He, who with your possession once is blest,
On easie terms may part with all the rest.
All my Ambition will in you be crown'd;
And those white Arms shall all my wishes bound.
Our life shall be but one long Nuptial day,
And, like chaf't Odours, melt in Sweats away.
Soft as the Night our Minutes shall be worn,
And chearful as the Birds that wake the Morn.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Thus hope misleads it self in pleasant way;
And takes mores joyes on trust then Love can pay!
But Love, with long possession, once decayd,
That face which now you Court, you will upbraid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: False Lovers broach these tenets, to remove
The fault from them by placing it on Love.â€”

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Yet grant in Youth you keep alive your Fire,
Old age will come, and then it must expire:
Youth but a while does at Loves Temple stay,
As some fair Inn to lodge it on the way.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your doubts are kind; but to be satisfy'd,
I can be t â€¢ ue, I beg I may be try'd.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Tryals of love too dear the making cost;
For, if successless, the whole venture's lost.
What you propose, brings wants and care along.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Love can bear both. (Cand.) but is your love so strong?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: They do not want, who wish not to have more;
Who ever said an Anchoret was poor?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: To answer gen'rously as you have done,
I should not by your arguments be wonn:
I know I urge your ruine by consent;
Yet love too well that ruine to prevent.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Like water giv'n to those whom Feavers fry,
You kill but him, who must without it die.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Secure me I may love without a Crime;
Then, for our flight, appoint both place and time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Th'ensuing hour my plighted vows shall be;
The time's not long; or onely long to me.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then, let us go where we shall ne'r be seen
By my hard Mother (Phil.) or my cruel Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen above.
sp.l: O Philocles unkind to call me cruel!
So false Aeneas did from Dido fly;
But never branded her with cruelty.
How I despise my self for loving so!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: At once you hate your self and love him too.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No, his ingratitude has cur'd my wound:
A painful cure indeed! (Ast.) and yet not sound.
His ignorance of your true thoughts
Excuses this; you did seem cruel, Madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But much of kindness still was mix'd with it.
Who could mistake so grosly not to know
A Cupid frowning when he draws his Bowe?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: He's going now to smart for his offence:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Should he without my leave depart from hence?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: No matter; since you hate him, let him go.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But I my hate by my revenge will show:
Besides, his head's a forfeit to the State.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: When you take that I will believe you hate.
Let him possess, and then he'll soon repen â€¢
And so his Crime will prove his punishment.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He may repent; but he will first possess:

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: O, Madam, now your hatred you confess:
If, his possessing her your rage does move,
'Tis jealousie the avarice of love.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No more, Asteria.
Seek Lysimantes out, bid him set Guards through all the Court and City.
Prevent their marriage first; then stop their flight.
Some fitting punishments I will ordain,
But speak not you of Philocles again:
'Tis bold to search, and dangerous to find,
Too much of Heaven's, or of a Princes mind.
sp.stage: As the Queen has done speaking, Flavia is going hastily over the Stage; Asteria sees her.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Flavia, Flavia, Whither so fast?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Did you call, Asteria?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: The Queen has business with Prince Lysimantes;
Speak to any Gentleman that's next, to fetch him.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I suspect somewhat, but I'le watch you close;
Prince Lysimantes has not chose in me,
The worst Spy of the Court.â€”Celadon! what makes he here!
sp.stage: Enter Celadon, Olinda, Sabina; they walk over the Stage together, he seeming to court them.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Nay, sweet Celadon.â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Nay, dear Celadon.â€”

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: O-ho. I see his business now, 'tis with Melissa's two Daughters: Look look, how he peeps about to see if the Coast be clear; like an Hawk that will not plume if she be look'd on.â€” Exeunt Cel. Ol. Sab. Soâ€”at last he has truss'ed his quarry.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Did you see Celadon this way?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: If you had not ask'd the question, I should have thought you had come from watching him; he's just gone off with Melissa's Daughters.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Melissa's Daughters! he did not Court 'em I hope?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: So busily, he lost no time: while he was teaching the one a tune, he was kissing the others hand.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: O fine Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: And they so greedy of him! Did you never see two Fishes about a Bait, tugging it this way, and t'other way; for my part, I look'd at least he should have lost a Leg or Arm i'th service.â€”Nay never vex your self, but e en resolve to break with him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: No no, 'tis not come to that, yet; I'le correct him first, and then hope the best from time.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p:
From time! Believe me, there's little good to be expected from him. I never knew the old Gentleman with the Scythe and Hourglass
bring any thing but gray hair, thin cheeks, and loss of teeth: you see Celadon loves others.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: There's the more hope he may love me among the rest: hang't, I would not marry one of these solemn Fops; they are good for nothing but to make Cuckolds: Give me a servant that is an high Flier at all games, that is bounteous of himself to many women; and yet whenever I pleas'd to throw out the lure of Matrimony, should come down with a swing, and fly the better at his own quarry.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: But are you sure you can take him down when you think good?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Nothing more certain.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: What wager will you venture upon the Trial?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: My Maydenhead to yours.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: That's a good one, who shall take the forfeit?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I'le go and write a Letter as from these two Sisters, to summon him immediately; it shall be deliver'd before you. I warrant you see a strange combat betwixt the Flesh and the Spirit: if he leaves you to go to them, you'l grant he loves them better?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Not a jot the more: a Bee may pick of many Flowers, and yet like some one better then all the rest.

sp.speaker: Flav,
sp.l: But then your Bee must not leave his sting behind him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Well; make the experiment however: I hear him coming, and a whole noise of Fiddles at his heels. Hey-day, what a mad Husband shall I have?â€”

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: And what a mad wife will he have? Well, I must goe a little way, but I'le return immediately and write it: You'l keep him in discourse the while?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Where are you, Madam? what do you mean to run away thus? pray stand to't, that we may dispatch this busine â€¢ s.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I think you mean to watch me as they do Witches, to make me confess I love you. Lord, what a bustle have you kept this Afternoon? what with eating, singing and dancing, I am so wearied, that I shall not be in case to hear of any more love this fortnight.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Nay, if you surfeit on't before Tryal, Lord have mercy upon you when I have married you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But what Kings Revenue do you think will maintain this extravagant expence?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I have a damnable Father, a rich old Rogue, if he would once die! Lord, how long does he mean to make it ere he dies!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: As long as ever he can, I'le pass my word for him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I think then we had best consider him as an obstinate old fellow that is deaf to the news of a better world; and ne're stay for him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But e'en marry; and get him Grandchildren in abundance, and great Grandchildren upon them, and so inch him and shove him out of the world by the very force of new Generations:â€”If that be the way you must excuse me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But dost thou know what it is to be an old Maid?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No, nor hope I sha'n't these twenty years.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: But when that time comes, in the first place thou wilt be condemned to tell Stories, how many men thou mightest have had; and none believe thee: Then thou growest froward, and impudently weariest all thy Friends to sollicite Man for thee.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Away with your old Common-place wit: I am resolved to grow fat and look young till forty, and then slip out of the world with the first wrinckle, and the reputation of five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well, what think you now of a reckoning betwixt us?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: To discount for so many dayes of my years service, as I have paid in since morning.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Inprimis, For a Treat:
Item, For my Glass Coach:
Item, For sitting bare, and wagging your Fann:
And lastly, and principally, for my Fidelity to you this long hour and half,

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: For this I'bate you three Weeks of your Service; now hear your Bill of Faults; for your comfort 'tis a short one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Inprimis, Item, and Sum totall, for keeping company with Melissa's Daughters.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: How the Pox came you to know of that: 'Gad I believe the Devil plays booty against himself, and tels you of my fins.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: The offence being so small the punishment shall be but proportionable, I will set you back onely half a year.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: You're most unconscionable: why then do you think we shall come together? there's none but the old Patriarchs could live long enough to marry you at this rate. What do you take me for some Cousin of Methusalem's, that I must stay an hundred years before I come to beget Sons and Daughters?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Heres an impudent Lover, he complains of me without ever off ring to excuse himself; Item, a fortnight more for that.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: So ther's another puff in my voyage has blown me back to the North of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: All this is nothing to your excuse for the two Sisters.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Faith if ever I did more then kiss 'em, and that but onceâ€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What could you have done more to me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: An hundred times more; as thou shalt know, dear Rogue, at time convenient.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You talk, you talk; Could you kiss 'em, though but once, and ne're think of me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Nay if I had thought of thee, I had kiss'd 'em over a thousand times, with the very force of imagination.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: The Gallants are mightily beholding to you, you have found 'em out a new way to kiss their Mistresses, upon other womens lips.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What would you have? You are my Sultana Queen, the rest are but in the nature of your Slaves; I may make some slight excursion into the Enemies Country for forage or so, but I ever return to my head quarters.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To me?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: If your name be Celadon.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: He's swallowing the Pill; presently we shall see the operation.

Child, come hither Child; here's money for thee: So, be gone quickly good Child, before any body examines thee: Thou art in a dangerous place, Child.â€” [Thrusts him out. Very good, the Sisters send me word they will have the Fiddles this Afternoon, and invites me to sup there!â€”Now cannot I forbear and I should be damn'd, though I have scap'd a scouring so lately for
it. Yet I love Florimel better then both of 'em together;â€”there's the Riddle o'nt: but onely for the sweet sake of variety.â€” [Aside. Well, we must all sin, and we must all repent, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What is it that makes you fidg up and down so?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: 'Faith I am sent for by a very dear friend, and 'tis upon a business of life and death.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: On my life some woman?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: On my honour some man; Do you think I would lye to you?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: But you engag'd to sup with me!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But I consider it may be scandalous to stay late in your Lodgings.
Adieu dear Miss if ever I am false to thee again.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: See what constant metal you men are made of! He begins to vex me in good earnest. Hang him, let him go and take enough of 'em: and yet methinks I can't endure he should neither. Lord, that such a Mad-Cap as I should ever live to be jealous!
sp.l: I must after him.
Some Ladies would discard him now, but I
A fitter way for my revenge will find,
Ile marry him, and serve him in his kind.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE, The Walks.
div.stage: Melissa, after her Olinda and Sabina.

sp.speaker: Melissa,
sp.p:
I Must take this business up in time: this wild fellow begins to haunt my house again. Well, I'le be bold to say it, 'tis as easie to bring up a young Lyon, without mischief, as a Maidenhead of Fifteen, to make it tame for an Husbands bed. Not but that the young man is handsome, rich and young, and I could be content he should marry one of 'em but to seduce 'em both in this manner.â€”Well, I'le examine 'em apart, and if I can find out
which he loves, 'Ile offer him his choice.â€”Olinda, Come hither Child.â€”

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Your pleasure, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nothing but for your good Olinda, what think you of Celadon?

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Why I think he's a very mad fellow; but yet I have some obligements to him: he teaches me new ayres on the Guitarre, and talks wildely to me, and I to him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But tell me in earnest, do you think he loves you?

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Can you doubt it? There were never two so cut out for one another; we both love Singing, Dancing, Treats and Musick. In short, we are each others counterpart.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But does he love you seriously?

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Seriously! I know not that; if he did, perhaps I should not love him: but we sit and talk, and wrangle, and are friends; when we are together we never hold our tongues; then we have always a noise of Fiddles at our heels, he hunts me merrily as the Hound does the Hare; and either this is Love, or I know it not.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well, go back, and call Sabina to me.

This is a Riddle past my finding out: whether he loves her or no is the question; but this I am sure of, she loves him:â€”O my little Favourite, I must ask you a question concerning Celadon: Is he in love with you?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I think indeed he does not hate me, at least if a mans word may be taken for it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But what expressions has he made you?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Truly the man has done his part: he has spoken civilly to me, and I was not so young but I understood him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And you could be content to marry him?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I have sworn never to marry; besides, he's a wild young man; yet to obey you, Mother, I could be content to be sacrific'd.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: No, no, we wou'd but lead you to the Altar.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Not to put off the Gentleman neither; for if I have him not I am resolv'd to die a Maid, that's once, Mother.â€”

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Both my Daughters are in love with him, and I cannot yet find he loves either of 'em.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Mother, mother, yonder's Celadon in the walks.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Peace wanton; you had best ring the Bells for joy. Well, I'le not meet him, because I know not which to offer him; yet he seems to like the youngest best: I le give him opportunity with her; Olinda, do you make haste after me.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: This is something hard though.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: You see Ladies the least breath of yours brings me to you: I have been seeking you at your Lodgings, and from thence came hither after you.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: 'T was well you found us.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Found you! Half this brightness betwixt you two was enough to have lighted me; I could never miss my way: Here's fair Olinda has beauty enough for one Family; such a voice, such a wit, so noble a stature, so white a skin.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: I thought he would be particular at last.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And young Sabina, so sweet an innocence, Such a Rose-bud newly blown.
This is my goodly Pallace of Love, and that my little withdrawing Room. A word, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I like not thisâ€” [aside.] Sir, if you are not too busie with my Sister, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I come, Madam.â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Time enough Sir; pray finish your Discourse,â€”and as you were a saying, Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Sweet Sir.â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Sister, you forget, my Mother bid you make haste.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Well, go you and tell her I am coming.â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p:
I ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ never endure to be the Messenger of ill news; but if you plea â€¢â€¢
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ send her word you won't come.â€”

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Minion, Minion, remember this.â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: She's horribly in love with you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Lord, who could love that walking Steeple: She's so high that every time She sings to me, I am looking up for the Bell that tolls to Church.â€”Ha! Give me my little Fifth-rate! that lies so snug.â€”She, hang her, a Duch built bottom: she's so tall, there's no boarding her. But we lose timeâ€”Madam, let me seal my love upon your mouth.
Soft and sweet by Heaven! sure you wear Rose-leaves between your lips.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Lord, Lord; What's the matter with me! my breath grows so short I can scarce speak to you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No matter, give me thy lips again and I'le speak for thee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: You don't love me.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I warrant thee; set down by me and kiss again.â€”â€”â€”
She warms faster then Pygmalion's Image.â€”
â€”I marry sir, this was the original use of lips; talking, eating, and drinking came in bith' by.â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Nay pray be civil; will you be at quiet?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What would you have me set still and look upon you like a little Puppy dog that's taught to beg with his fore-leg up?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Celadon the faithful! in good time Sir.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: In very good time Florimell; for Heavens sake help me quickly.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Do not you see! here's a poor Gentlewoman in a swoon! (swoon away!) I have been rubbing her this half hour, and cannot bring her to her senses.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Alas, how came she so?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Oh barbarous! do you stay to ask questions, run for charity.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Help, help, alas poor Lady.â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Is she gone?

sp.speaker: Cel.
