sp.p: I thanks to my wit that helpt me at a pinch; I thank Heaven, I never pumpt for a lye in all my life yet.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: I am affraid you love her, Celadon!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Onely as a civil acquaintance or so, but however to avoid slander you had best be gone before she comes again.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: I can find a tongue as well as sheâ€”â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I, but the truth is, I am a kind of scandalous person, and for you to be seen in my companyâ€”Stay in the walks, by this kiss I'le be with you presently.â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Flor,
sp.l: Help, help, I can find no body.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: 'Tis needless now my dear, she's recover'd, and gone off, but so wan and weakly.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Umh! I begin to smell a ratt, what was your business here, Celadon?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Charity, Christian charity; you saw I was labouring for life with her.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But how came you hither; not that I care this,â€”but onely to be satisfiedâ€”â€”â€”â€”.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You are jealous in my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Who I jealous! Then I wish this sigh may be the last that ever I may draw.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But why do you sigh then?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Nothing but a cold, I cannot fetch my breath well.â€”â€”But what will you say if I write the Letter you had, to try your faith?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Hey-day! This is just the Devil and the Sinner; you lay snares for me, and then punish me for being taken; here's trying a man's Faith indeed: What did you think I had the faith of a Stock, or of a Stone? Nay, and you go to tantalize a man,â€”'gad I love upon the square, I can endure no tricks to be used to me.
sp.stage: Olinda and Sabina at the door Peeping.

sp.speaker: Ol. and Sab.
sp.l: Celadon, Celadon!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What voices are those?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Some Camerades of mine that call me to play;â€”â€”â€”Pox on 'em, they'l spoil allâ€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pray let's see 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Hang 'em Tatterdemallions, they are not worth your sight; 'pray Gentlemen be gone, I'le be with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: No, we'll stay here for you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Do your Gentlemen speak with Treble-voices.? I am resolv'd to see what company you keep.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay, good my Dear.â€”â€”
sp.stage: He lays hold of her to pull her back; she lays hold of Olinda, by whom Sabina holds; so that he pulling, they all come in.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Are these your Comerades?
'Tis Strephon calls what would my love?

Why do not you roar out like a great Bass-vyal, Come follow to the Myrtle-grove. Pray Sir, which of these fair Ladies is it, for whom you were' to do the courtesie, for it were unconscionable to leave you to 'em both; What a man's but a man you know.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: The Gentleman may find an owner.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Though not of you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pray agree whose the lost sheep is, and take him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Slife they'l cry me anon, and tell my marks.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Troth I pity your Highness there, I perceive he has left you for the little one: Me thinks he should have been affraid to break his neck when he fell so high as from you to her.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well my drolling Lady, I may be even with you.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Not this ten years by thy growth, yet.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Can flesh and blood endure this!â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: How now, my Amazon in decimo sexto!â€”

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Do you affront my Sister?â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I, but thou art so tall, I think I shall never affront thee.â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come away Sister, we shall be jeer'd to Death else.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why do you look that way, you can'nt forbear leering after the forbidden Fruit.â€”â€”But when e're I take a Wenchers word again!â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: A Wenchers word! Why should you speak so contemptibly of the better half of Mankind. I'le stand up for the honour of my Vocation.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You are in no fault I warrant;â€”'ware my buskâ€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Not to give a fair Lady the lye, I am in fault;â€”but otherwise.â€”Come let us be friends; and let me wait you to your Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: This impudence shall not save you from my Table-book. Item. A Month more for this fault.â€”

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier within.
sp.l: Stand.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.l: Stand, give the word.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now, whats the meaning of this trow, guards set.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Give the word, or you cannot pass; these are they brother; let's in, and seize em.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: â€”Down with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.l: Disarm him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How now Rascalls;â€”
sp.stage: Draws and beats one off, and catches the other,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ask your life you villain.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.l: Quarter, quarter.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Was ever such an Insolence?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: We did but our duty; here we were set, to take a Gentleman and Lady, that would steal a marriage without the Queens consent, and we thought you had been they.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Your Cousin Philocles and the Princess Candiope on my life! for I heard the Queen give private Orders to Lysimantes, and name them twice or thrice.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I know a score or two of Madcaps here hard by, whom I can pick up from Taverns and Gaming-houses, and Bordells; those I'le bring to aid him: Now Florimell, there's an argument for wenching; where would you have had so many honest men together upon the sudden for a brave employment?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You'l leave me then to take my fortune?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No; if you will, I'le have you into the places aforesaid, and enter you into good company.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Thank you Sir, here's a key will let me through this backdoor to my own Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: If I come off with life, I'le see you this evening, if notâ€”Adieu Florimell.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: If you come not I shall conclude you are kill'd, or taken; to be hang'd for a Rebel tomorrow morning,â€”and then I'le honour your memory with a Lampoon instead of an Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No no, I trust better in my Fate: I know I am reserv'd to do you a Courtesie.
sp.stage: As Florimell is unlocking the door to go out; Flavia opens it against her, and enters to her, followed by a Page.

sp.speaker: Flav. and Florimel.
sp.l: do you hear the News?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I guess they are in pursuit of Philocles.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: When Lysimantes came with the Queens Orders,
He refused to render up Candiope;
And with some few brave friends he had about him
Is forcing of his way through all the Guards.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: A gallant fellow: I'le in, will you with me.
Hark, the noise comes this way!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I have a message from the Queen to Lysimantes,
I hope I may be safe among the Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Oh very safe, perhaps some honest fellow in the tumult may take pity of thy Maidenhead, or soâ€”Adiew.

sp.speaker: Page 1.
sp.l: The noise comes nearer, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I am glad on't: this message gives me the opportunity of speaking privately with Lysimantes.
sp.stage: Enter Philocles and Candiope, with three friends; pursued by Lysimantes and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What is it renders you thus obstinate? you have no hope of flight, and to resist is full as vain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'le die, rather then yield her up.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: how now, some new message from the Queen?
Retire a while to a convenient distance.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: O Flavia 'tis impossible! the Queen in love with Philocles!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I half suspected it before; but now,
My ears and eyes are witnesses.â€”
This hour I over-heard her to Asteria.
Making such sad complaints of her hard fate!
For my part I believe you lead him back
But to his Coronation.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Hell take him first.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Presently after this she call'd for me,
And bid me run, and with strict care command you
On peril of your life he had no harm:
But, Sir, she spoke it with so great concernment,
Me thought I saw love, anger and despair
All combating at once upon her face.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Tell the Queenâ€”I know not what, I am distracted so;â€”
But go and leave me to my thoughts.â€”
Was ever such amazing news
Told in so strange and critical a moment!
What shall I do!
Does she love Philocles, who loves not her;
And loves not Lysimantes who prefers her
Above his life! what rests but that I take
This opportunity, which she her self
Has given me, to kill this happy Rival!
Assist me Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: They shall buy me dearly.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Ah me, unhappy maid!
sp.stage: Enter Celadon with his Friends, unbutton'd and reeling.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Courage my noble Cousin, I have brought
A band of Blades, the bravest youths of Syracuse:
Some drunk, some sober, all resolv'd to run
Your fortune to the utmost. Fall on mad Boyesâ€”â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Hold, a little;â€”
I'm not secur'd of victory against these desperate ruffins.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No, but I'le secure you; they shall cut your throat for such another word of 'em. Ruffins quoth a! call Gamesters, and Whoremasters, and Drunkards, Ruffins!â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Pray Gentlemen fall back a littleâ€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O ho, are they Gentlemen now with you!
Speak first to your Gentlemen Souldiers to retire; and then
I'le spe â€¢ k to my Gentlemen Ruffians.
There's your disciplin'd men now.â€”
sp.stage: They sing and the Souldiers retire on both sides.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, let's lose no time; while they are talking, let's have one merry mayn before we dieâ€”for Mortality sake.

sp.l: Agreed, here's my Cloak for a Table.
And my Hat for a Box.â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Suppose I kill'd him!
'Twould but exasperate the Queen the more:
He loves not her, nor knows he she loves him:
A sudden thought is come into my headâ€”
So to contrive it, that this Philocles,
And these his friends shall bring to pass that for me
Which I could never compass.â€”True I strain
A point of honour; but then her usage to me, it shall be soâ€”
Pray, Philocles, command your Souldiers off,
As I will mine: I've somewhat to propose
Which you perhaps may like.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I will not leave him.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: â€”'Tis my desire you should not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: â€”Cousin, lead off your friends.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: â€”One word in your ear Couz. Let me advise you; either make your own conditions, or never agree with him: his men are poor sober Rogues, they can never stand before us.
sp.stage: Exeunt omnes praeter Lys. Phil. Cand.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Suppose some friend, e're night,
Should bring you to possess all you desire;
And not so onely, but secure for ever
The Nations happinessâ€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would think of him
As of some God, or Angel.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: That God or Angel you and I may be to one another,
We have betwixt us
An hundred men; The Cittadel you govern:
What were it now to seize the Queen!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O impiety! to seize the Queen!
To seize her, said you?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: The word might be too rough, I meant secure her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Was this your proposition,
And had you none to make it to but to me?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Pray hear me out e're you condemn me:
I would not the least violence were offer'd
Her person; two small grants is all I ask,
To make me happy in her self, and you
In your Candiope.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: And will not you do this, my Philocles?
Nay now my Brother speaks but reason.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Int'rest makes all seem reason that leads to it.
Int'rest that does the zeal of Sects create,
To purge a Church, and to reform a State.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: In short, the Queen hath sent to part you two;
What more she means to her, I know not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To her! alas! why will not you protect her?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: With you I can; but where's my power alone?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: You know she loves me not: you lately heard her
How she insulted over me: how she
Despis'd that beauty which you say I have;
I see she purposes my death.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why do you fright me with it?
'Tis in your Brothers pow'r to let us 'scape,
And then you run no danger.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: True, I may;
But then my head must pay the forfeit of it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O wretched Philocles, whither would love
Hurry thee headlong!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Cease these exclamations.
Ther's no danger on your side: 'tis but
To live without my Sister, resolve that
And you have shot the gulf.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To live without her! is that nothing think you?
The damn'd in Hell endure no greater pain
Then seeing Heaven from far with hopeless eyes.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Candiope must die, and die for you;
See it not unreveng'd at least.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha, unreveng'd! on whom should I revenge it?
But yet she dies, and I may hinder it;
'Tis I then murder my Candiope:
And yet should I take armes against my Queen!
That favour'd me, rais'd me to what I am!
Alas, it must not be.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: He cools again.â€”
True; she once favour'd you;
But now I am inform'd,
She is besotted on an upstart wretch;
So far, that she intends to make him Master,
Both of her Crown and person.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Knows he that!
Then, what I dreaded most is come to pass.â€”
I am convinc'd of the necessity;
Let us make haste to raze
That action from Annals of her Reign:
No motive but her glory could have wrought me.
I am a Traytor to her, to preserve her
From Treason to her self; and yet Heav'n knows
With what a heavy heart
Philocles turns reformer: but have care
This fault of her strange passion take no air.
Let not the vulgar blow upon her fame.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I will be careful, shall we go my Lord:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Time wasts apace; Each first prepare his men.
Come my Candiope.â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: This ruines him forever with the Queen;
The odium's half his, the profit all my own.
Those who, like me, by others help would climb,
To make 'em sure, must dip 'em in their crime.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No more news yet from Philocles?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: None, Madam, since Flavia's return!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O my Asteria, if you lov'd me, sure
You would say something to me of my Philocles;
I could speak ever of him.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Madam, you commanded me no more to name him to you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then I command you now to speak of nothing else:
I charge you here, on your allegiance, tell me
What I should do with him.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: When you gave orders that he should be taken,
You seem'd resolv'd how to dispose of him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Dull Asteria not to know,
Mad people never think the same thing twice.
Alas, I'm hurried restless up and down,
I was in anger once, and then I thought
I had put into shore!
But now a gust of love blows hard against me,
And bears me off again.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Shall I sing the Song you made of Philocles,
And call'd it Secret-love.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Do, for that's all kindness: and while thou sing'st it,
I can think nothing but what pleases me.

lg.l: I Feed a flame within which so torments me
That it both pains my heart, and yet contents me:
'Tis such a pleasing smart, and I so love it,
That I had rather die, then once remove it.
Yet he for whom I grieve shall never know it,
My tongue does not betray, nor my eyes show it:
Not a sigh nor a tear my pain discloses,
But they fall silently like dew on Roses.
Thus to prevent my love from being cruel,
My heart's the sacrifice as 'tis the fuel:
And while I suffer this to give him quiet,
My faith rewards my love, though he deny it.
On his eyes will I gaze, and there delight me;
While I conceal my love, no frown can fright me:
To be more happy I dare not aspire;
Nor can I fall more low, mounting no higher.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Peace: Me thinks I hear the noise
Of clashing Swords, and clatt'ring Armes, below.
Now; what news that you press in so rudely?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Madam, the worst that can be;
Your Guards upon the sudden are surpris'd,
Disarm'd, some slain, all scatter'd.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Prince Lysimantes, and Lord Philocles.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It cannot be; Philocles is a Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: What my eyes sawâ€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Pull 'em out, they are false Spectacles.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: O vertue, impotent and blind as Fortune!
Who would be good, or pious, if this Queen
Thy great Example suffers!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Peace, Asteria, accuse not vertue;
She has but given me a great occasion
Of showing what I am when Fortune leaves me.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Philocles, to do this!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I, Philocles, I must confess 'twas hard!
But there's a fate in kindness
Still, to be least return'd where most 'tis given.
Where's Candiope?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Philocles was whispering to her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hence Screech-owl; call my Guards quickly there:
Put 'em apart in several Prisons.
Alas! I had forgot I have no Guards,
But those which are my Jaylors.
Never till now unhappy Queen:
The use of pow'r, till lost, is seldom known;
Now I would strike, I find my Thunder gone.
sp.stage: Philocles enters, and meets Asteria going out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Asteria! Where's the Queen?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Ah my Lord what have you done!
I came to seek you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is it from her you come?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: No, but on her behalf: her heart's too great,
In this low ebb of Fortune, to intreat.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis but a short Ecclipse,
Which past, a glorious day will soon ensue:
But I would ask a favour too, from you.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: When Conquerors petition, they command:
Those that can Captive Queens, who can withstand?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She, with her happiness, might mine create;
'Yet seems indulgent to her own ill fate:
But she, in secret, hates me fure; for why
If not, should she Candiope deny?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: If you dare trust my knowledg of her mind,
She has no thoughts of you that are unkind.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I could my sorrows with some patience bear,
Did they proceed from any one but her:
But from the Queen! whose person I adore,
By Duty much, by inclination more.â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: He is inclin'd already, did he know
That she lov'd him, how would his passion grow!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That her fair hand with Destiny combines!â€”
Fate ne're strikes deep, but when unkindness joynes!
For, to confess the secret of my mind,
Something so tender for the Queen I find,
That ev'n Candiope can scarce remove,
And, were she lower, I should call it love.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: She charg'd me not this secret to betray,
But I best serve her if I disobey:
For, if he loves, 'twas for her int'rest done;
If not, he'll keep it secret for his own.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why are you in obliging me so slow?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: The thing's of great importance you would know;
And you must first swear secresie to all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I swear:

sp.speaker: (Ast.)
sp.l: Yet hold; your oath's too general:
Swear that Candiope shall never know.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I swear:

sp.speaker: (Ast.)
sp.l: No not the Queen her self:

sp.speaker: (Phil.)
sp.l: I vow.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: You wonder why I am so cautious grown
In telling, what concerns your self alone:
But spare my Vow, and guess what it may be
That makes the Queen deny Candiope:
'Tis neither hate nor pride that moves her mind;
Methinks the Riddle is not hard to find.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You seem so great a wonder to intend,
As were, in me, a crime to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: 'Tis not a crime, to know; but would be one
To prove ungrateful when your Duty's known.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why would you thus my easie faith abuse!
I cannot think the Queen so ill would chuse.
But stav, now your imposture will appear;
She has her self confess'd she lov'd elsewhere:
Or some ignoble choice has plac'd her heart,
One who wants quality, and more, desert.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This, though unjust, you have most right to say,
For, if you'l rail against your self, you may

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dull that I was!
A thousand things now crowd my memory
That make me know it could be none but I.
Her Rage was Love: and its tempestuous flame,
Like Lightning, show'd the Heaven from whence it came.
But in her kindness my own shame I see;
Have I dethron'd her then, for loving me?
I hate my self for that which I have done,
Much more, discover'd, then I did unknown.
How does she brook her strange imprisonment?

sp.speaker: Ast
sp.l: As great souls should, that make their own content.
The hardest term she for your act could find
Was onely this, O Philocles, unkind!
Then, setting free a sigh, from her fair eyes
She wip'd two pearls, the remnants of mild show'rs,
Which hung, like drops upon the bells of flowers:
And thank'd the Heav'ns,
Which better did, what she design'd, pursue,
Without her crime to give her pow'r to you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold, hold, you set my thoughts so near a Crown,
They mount above my reach to pull them down:
Here Constancy; Ambition there does move;
On each side Beauty, and on both sides Love.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Me thinks the least you can is to receive
This love, with reverence, and your former leave.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Think but what difficulties come between!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: 'Tis wond'rous difficult to love a Queen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For pity cease more reasons to provide,
I am but too much yielding to your side;
And, were my heart but at my own dispose,
I should not make a scruple where to choose.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Then if the Queen will my advice approve,
Her hatred to you shall expel her love.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not to be lov'd by her, as hard would be
As to be hated by Candiope.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I leave you to resolve while you have time;
You must be guilty, but may choose your crime.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: One thing I have resolv'd; and that I'le do
Both for my love, and for my honour too.
But then, (Ingratitude and falshood weigh'd,)
I know not which would most my soul upbraid.
Fate shoves me headlong down, a rugged way;
Unsafe to run, and yet too steep to stay.

sp.p: 'T Will be rare now if I can go through with it, to out-do this mad Celadon in all his tricks, and get both his Mistresses from him; then I shall revenge my self upon all three, and save my own stake into the bargain; for I find I do love the Rogue in spight of all his infidelities. Yonder they are, and this way they must come.â€”if cloathes and a bon meen will take 'em, I shall do't.â€”Save you Monsieur Florimell; Faith me thinks you are a very janty fellow, poudrÃ© & ajustÃ© as well as the best of 'em. I can manage the little Comb,â€”set my Hat, shake my Garniture, toss about my empty Noddle, walk with a courant slurr, and at every step peck down my Head:â€”if I should be mistaken for some Courtier now, pray where's the difference?â€”
sp.stage: Enter to her Celadon, Olinda, Sabina.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Never mince the matter!

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: You have left your heart behind with Florimell; we know it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: You know you wrong me; when I am with Florimell 'tis still your Prisoner, it onely draws a longer chain after it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Is it e'en so! then farwell poor Florimell, thy Maidenhead is condemned to die with theeâ€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: But let's leave the discourse; 'tis all digression that does not speak of your beauties.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Now for me in the name of impudence!â€” [walks with them. They are the greatest beauties I confess that ever I beheld.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How now, what's the meaning of this young fellow?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: And therefore I cannot wonder that this Gentleman who has the honour to be known to you should admire you,â€”since I that am a strangerâ€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And a very impudent one, as I take it, Sir.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Am so extreamly surpriz'd, that I admire, love, am wounded, and am dying all in a moment.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I have seen him somewhere, but where I know not! prithee my friend leave us, dost thou think we do not know our way in Court?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I pretend not to instruct you in your way; you see I do not go before you! but you cannot possibly deny me the happiness to wait upon these Ladies; me, who.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Thee, who shalt be beaten most unmercifully if thou dost follow them!â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You will not draw in Court I hope!â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pox on him, let's walk away faster, and be rid of him.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: O take no care for me, Sir, you shall not lose me, I'le rather mend my pace then not wait on you.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: I begin to like this fellow.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: You make very bold here in my Seraglio, and I shall find a time to tell you so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: When you find a time to tell me on't, I shall find a time to answer you: But pray what do you find in your self so extraordinary, that you should serve these Ladies better then I; let me know what 'tis you value your self upon, and let them Judg betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am somewhat more a man then you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: That is, you are so much older then I: Do you like a man ever the better for his age Ladies?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well said, young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Pish, thee! a young raw Creature, thou hast ne're been under the Barbers hands yet.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No, nor under the Surgeons neither as you have been.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Slife what wouldst thou be at, I am madder then thou art?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: The Devil you are; I'le Tope with you, I'le Sing with you, I'le Dance with you,â€”I'le Swagger with you.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'le fight with you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Out upon fighting; 'tis grown so common a fashion, that a Modish man contemns it; A man of Garniture and Feather is above the dispensation of the Sword.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Uds my life, here's the Queens Musick just going to us; you shall decide your quarrel by a Dance.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Who stops the Fiddles?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Base and Trebble, by your leaves we arrest you at these Ladies suits.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Come on Sirs, play me a Jigg,
You shall see how I'le baffle him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Your judgment, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: You sir, you sir: This is the rarest Gentleman: I could live and die with him.â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Lord how he Sweats! please you Sir to make use of my Handkerchief:

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: You and I are merry, and just of an humour Sir; therefore we two should love one another.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: And you and I are just of an age Sir, and therefore me thinks we should not hate one another.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Then I perceive Ladies I am a Castaway, a Reprobate with you: why faith this is hard luck now, that I should be no less then one whole hour in getting your affections, and now must lose 'em in a quarter of it.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: No matter, let him rail, does the loss afflict you Sir?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No in faith does it not; for if you had not forsaken me, I had you: so the Willows may flourish for any branches I shall rob 'em of.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: However we have the advantage to have left you; not you us.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: That's onely a certain nimbleness in Nature you women have to be first unconstant: but if you had not made the more haste, the wind was veering too upon my Weathercock: the best on't is Florimell is worth both of you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis like she'll accept of their leavings.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: She will accept on't, and she shall accept on't; I think I know more then you of her mind Sir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Daughters there's a poor collation within that waits for you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Will you walk musty Sir?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No merry Sir; I won'not; I have surfeited of that old womans face already.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Begin some frolick then; what will you do for her?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Faith I am no dog to show tricks for her; I cannot come aloft for an old Woman.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Dare you kiss her!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I was never dar'd by any man.â€”by your leave old Madam.â€”

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Help, help, do you discover my nakedness?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Peace Tiffany! no harm.
Now Sir here's Florimels health to you.â€”

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Away sir:â€”a sweet young man as you are to abuse the gifts of Nature so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Good Mother do not commend me so; I am flesh and blood, and you do not know what you may pluck upon that reverend person of yours.â€”Come on, follow your leader.
sp.stage: [Gives Florimel the Ruff, she puts it on.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Stand fair Mother.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What with your Hat on? lie thou there;â€”and thou too.â€”
sp.stage: Plucks off her Hat and Perruke, and discovers Florimell.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Florimell!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: My kind Mistresses how sorry I am I can do you no further service! I think I had best resign you to Celadon to make amends for me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Lord what a misfortune it was Ladies, that the Gentleman could not hold forth to you.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: We have lost Celadon too.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Come away; this is past enduring.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, if ever I believe a man to be a man for the sake of a Perruks and Feather again.â€”

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Come Celadon, shall we make accounts even? Lord what a hanging look was there: indeed if you had been recreant to your Mistress, or had forsworn your love, that sinners face had been but decent, but for the vertuous, the innocent, the constant Celadon!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: This is not very heroick in you now to insult over a man in his misfortunes; but take heed, you have robb'd me of my two Mistresses; I shall grow desperately constant, and all the tempest of my love will fall upon your head: I shall so pay you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Who you, pay me! you are a banckrupt, cast beyond all possibility of recovery.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: If I am a banckrupt I'le be a very honest one; when I cannot pay my debts, at least I'le give you up the possession of my body.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: No, I'le deal better with you; since you're unable to pay, I'le give in your bond.
sp.stage: Enter Philocles with a Commanders Staff in his hand, Attended.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Cousin I am sorry I must take you from your company about an earnest business.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: There needs no excuse my Lord, we had dispatch'd our affairs, and were just parting.â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Will you be going Sir; sweet Sir, damn'd Sir, I have but one word more to say to you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: As I a man of Honour, I'le wait on you some other time.â€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: By these Breeches.â€”Flor. which if I marry you I am resolv'd to wear; put that into our Bargain, and so adieu Sir.â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hark you Cousinâ€”â€”
You'll see it exactly executed; I rely upon you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I shall not fail, my Lord; may the conclusion of it prove happy to you.
Wheree're I cast about my wond'ring eyes,
Greatness lies ready in some shape to tempt me.
The royal furniture in every room,
The Guards, and the huge waving crowds of people,
All waiting for a sight of that fair Queen
Who makes a present of her love to me:
Now tell me, Stoique!â€”
If all these with a wish might be made thine,
Would'st thou not truck thy ragged vertue for 'em?
If Glory was a bait that Angels swallow'd
How then should souls ally'd to sence, resist it!
Ah poor Candiope! I pity her,
But that is all.â€”

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: O my dear Philocles! A thousand blessings wait on thee!
The hope of being thine, I think will put
Me past my meat and sleep with extasie,
So I shall keep the fasts of Seraphim's,
And wake for joy like Nightingals in May.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wake Philocles, wake from thy dream of glory,
'Tis all but shadow to Candiope:
Canst thou betray a love so innocent!â€”

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What makes you melancholick? I doubt
I have displeased you?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No my love, I'am not displeas'd with you,
But with my self, when I consider
How little I deserve you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Say not so my Philocles, a love so true as yours
That would have left a Court, and a Queens favour
To live in a poor Hermitage with me.â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha! she has stung me to the quick!
As if she knew the falshood I intended:
But, I thank Heav'n, it has recal'd my vertue.â€”
O my dear, I love you, and you onely;
Go in I have some business for a while;
But I think minutes ages till we meet.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I knew you had; but yet I could not choose
But come and look upon you.â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What barbarous man could wrong so sweet a vertue!
sp.stage: Enter the Queen in black with Asteria.
sp.l: Madam, the States are straight to meet; but why
In these dark ornaments will you be seen?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: â€”They fit the fortune of a Captive Queen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: â€”Deep shades are thus to heighten colours set;
So Stars in Night, and Diamonds shine in Jet.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: True friends should so, in dark afflictions shine,
But I have no great cause to boast of mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You may have too much prejudice for some,
And think 'em false before their trial's come.
But, Madam, what determine you to do?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I come not here to be advis'd by you:
But charge you by that pow'r which once you own'd,
And which is still my right, ev'n when unthron'd;
That whatsoe're the States resolve of me,
You never more think of Candiope.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not think of her! ah, how should I obey!
Her tyrant eyes have forc'd my heart away.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: By force retake it from those tyrant eyes,
I'le grant you out my Letters of Reprize.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She has, too well, prevented that design
By giving me her heart in change for mine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thus foolish Indians Gold for Glass forgo,
'Twas to your loss you priz'd your heart so low.
I set its value when you were advanc'd.
And as my favours grew, its rate inhanc'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The rate of Subjects hearts by yours must go,
And love in yours has set the value low.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I stand corrected, and my self reprove,
You teach me to repent my low-plac'd love:
Help me this passion from my heart to tear,
Now rail on him, and I will sit and hear.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, like you, I have repented too,
And dare not rail on one I do not know.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: This, Philocles, like strange perverseness shows,
As if what e're I said, you would oppose;
How come you thus concern'd, for this unknown?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I onely judg his actions by my own.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I've heard too much, and you too much have said,
O Heav'ns, the secret of my soul's betray'd!
He knows my love, I read it in his face,
And blushes, conscious of his Queens disgrace.â€”
Hence quickly, hence, or I shall die with shame.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now I love both, and both with equal flame.
Wretched I came, more wretched I retire,
When two winds blow it who can quench the fire!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O my Asteria, I know not whom t'accuse;
But either my own eyes or you, have told
My love to Philocles.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Is't possible that he should know it, Madam!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Me thinks you ask'd that question guiltily.
Confess, for I will know, what was the subject of your long discourse
I'th Antichamber with him.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: It was my business to convince him, Madam,
How ill he did, being so much oblig'd,
To joyn in your imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay, now I am confirm'd my thought was true;
For you could give him no such reason
Of his obligements as my love.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Because I saw him much a Malecontent,
I thought to win him to your int'rest, Madam,
By telling him it was no want of kindness
Made your refusal of Candiope.
And he perhapsâ€”(Qu.) What of him now!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: As men are apt, interpreted my words
To all th'advantage he could wrest the sence,
As if I meant you Lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Have I deposited within thy breast
The dearest treasure of my life, my glory,
And hast thou thus betray'd me!
But why do I accuse thy female weakness,
And not my own for trusting thee!
Unhappy Queen, Philocles knows thy fondness,
And needs must think it done by thy Command.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Dear Madam, think not so.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Peace, peace, thou should'st for ever hold thy tongue.
For it has spoke too much for all thy life.â€”
Then Philocles has told Candiope,
And courts her kindness with his scorn of me.
O whither am I fallen! But I must rouze my self, and give a stop
To all these ills by headlong passion caus'd;
In hearts resolv'd weak love is put to flight,
And onely conquers when we dare not fight.
But we indulge our harms, and while he gains
An entrance, please our selves into our pains.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Prince Lysimantes, Madam!â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come near you poor deluded criminal;
See how ambition cheats you:
You thought to find a Prisoner here,
But you behold a Queen.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: And may you long be so: 'tis true this Act
May cause some wonder in your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: None, Cousin, none; I ever thought you
Ambitious, Proud, designing.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Yet all my Pride, Designs, and my Ambition
Were taught me by a Master
With whom you are not unacquainted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Explain your self; dark purposes, like yours,
Need an Interpretation.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: 'Tis love I mean. (Qu.) Have my low fortunes giv'n thee
This insolence, to name it to thy Queen?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Yet you have heard love nam'd without offence.
As much below you as you think my passion,
I can look down on yours.â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Does he know it too!
This is th'extreamest malice of my Stars!â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You see, that Princes faults,
(How e're they think 'em safe from publick view)
Fly out through the dark crannies of their Closets:
We know what the Sun does,
Ev'n when we see him not in t'other world.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My actions, Cousin, never fear'd the light.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Produce him then, your darling of the dark,
For such an one you have. (Qu.) I know no such.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You know, but will not own him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Rebels ne're want pretence to blacken Kings,
And this, it seems, is yours: do you produce him,
Or ne're hereafter sully my Renown
With this aspersion:â€”Sure he dares not name him.â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I am too tender of your fame; or elseâ€”
Nor are things brought to that extremity:
Provided you accept my passion,
I'le gladly yield to think I was deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Keep in your error still; I will not buy
Your good opinion at so dear a rate,
As my own misery by being yours.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Do not provoke my patience by such scornes,
For fear I break through all, and name him to you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hope not to fright me with your mighty looks;
Know I dare stem that tempest in your brow,
And dash it back upon you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Spight of prudence it will out: 'Tis Philocles.
Now judge, when I was made a property
To cheat my self by making him your Prisoner,
Whether I had not right to take up armes?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Poor envious wretch! was this the venome that swell'd up thy brest?
My grace to Philocles mis-deem'd my love!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: 'Tis true, the Gentleman is innocent;
He ne're sinn'd up so high, not in his wishes;
You know he loves elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You mean your Sister.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I wish some Sybil now would tell me
Why you refus'd her to him?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Perhaps I did not think him worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Did you not think him too worthy, Madam?
This is too thin a vail to hinder your passion,
To prove you love him not, yet give her him,
And I'le engage my honour to lay down my Armes

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He is arriv'd where I would wishâ€”
Call in the company, and you shall see what I will do.â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Who waits without there?â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now hold, my heart, for this one act of honour,
And I will never ask more courage of thee:
Once more I have the means to reinstate my self into my glory;
I feel my love to Philocles within me
Shrink, and pull back my heart from this hard tryal,
But it must be when glory says it must:
As children wading from some Rivers bank
First try the water with their tender feet;
Then shuddring up with cold, step back again,
And streight a little further venture on,
Till at the last they plunge into the deep,
And pass, at once, what they were doubting long:
I'le make the same experiment; it shall be done in haste,
Because I'le put it past my pow'r t'undo.
sp.stage: Enter at one door Lysimantes, at the other Philocles, Celadon, Candiope, Florimell, Flavia, Olinda, Sabina; the three Deputies, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: In Armes! is all well, Philocles?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, but it shall be.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He comes, and with him
The fevour of my love returns to shake me.
I see love is not banish'd from my soul,
He is still there, but is chain'd up by glory.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: You 've made a noble conquest, Madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come hither, Philocles: I am first to tell you
I and my Cousin are agreed, he has
Engag'd to lay down Armes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis well for him he has; for all his party
By my command already are surpriz'd,
While I was talking with your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Yes 'faith I have done him that courtesie; I brought his followers, under pretence of guarding it, to a straight
place where they are all coupt up without use of their Armes, and may be pelted to death by the small infantry o'the town.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: 'T was more then I expected, or could hope;
Yet still I thought your meaning honest.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My fault was rashness, but 'twas full of zeal:
Nor had I e're been led to that attempt,
Had I not seen it would be done without me:
But by compliance I preserv'd the pow'r
Which I have since made use of for your service.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And which I purpose so to recompence.â€”

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: With her Crown she means; I knew 'twould come to 't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O Heav'ns, she'll own her love!
Then I must lose Candiope for ever,
And floating in a vast abyss of glory,
Seek and not, find my self!â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Take your Candiope; and be as happy
As love can make you both:â€”how pleas'd I am
That I can force my tongue,
To speak words so far distant from my heart!â€”

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: My happiness is more then I can utter!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Methinks I could do violence on my self for taking Armes.
Against a Queen so good, so bountiful:
Give me leave, Madam, in my extasie
Of joy, to give you thanks for Philocles.
You have preserv'd my friend, and now he owes not
His fortunes onely to your favour; but
What's more, his life, and more then that, his love.
I am convinc'd, she never lov'd him now;
Since by her free consent, all force remov'd
She gives him to my Sister.
Flavia was an Impostor and deceiv'd me.â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As for me, Madam, I can onely say
That I beg respit for my thanks; for on the sudden,
The benefit's so great it overwhelmes me.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Mark but th' faintness of th' acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Qu. to Ast.]
sp.l: I have observ'd it with you, and am pleas'd
He seems not satisfi'd; for I still wish
That he may love me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I see Asteria deluded me
With flattering hopes of the Queens love
Onely to draw me off from Lysimantes:â€”
But I will think no more on't.
I'm going to possess Candiope,
And I am ravish'd with the joy on't! ha!
Not ravish'd neither.
For what can be more charming then that Queen!
Behold how night sits lovely on her eye-brows,
While day breaks from her eyes! then, a Crown too:
Lost, lost, for ever lost, and now 'tis gone
'Tis beautifull.â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: How he eyes you still!â€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sure I had one of the fallen Angels Dreams;
All Heav'n within this hour was mine!â€”â€”â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What is it that disturbs you Dear?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Onely the greatness of my joy:
I've ta'ne too strong a Cordial, love,
And cannot yet digest it.
'Tis done! but this pang more; and then a glorious birth.
The Tumults of this day, my loyal Subjects
Have setled in my heart a resolution,
Happy for you, and glorious too for me.
First for my Cousin, though attempting on my person,
He has incurr'd the danger of the Laws,
I will not punish him.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You bind me ever to my loyalty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then, that I may oblige you more to it.
I here declare you rightful successor,
And heir immediate to my Crown:
This, Gentlemen,â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
I hope will still my subjects discontents,
When they behold succession firmly setled.
Heav'n preserve your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: As for my self I have resolv'd
Still to continue as I am, unmarried:
The cares, observances, and all the duties
Which I should pay an Husband, I will place
Upon my people; and our mutual love
Shall make a blessing more then Conjugal.
And this the States shall ratifie.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Heav'n bear me witness that I take no joy
In the succession of a Crown.
Which must descend to me so sad away.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Cousin, no more; my resolution's past,
Which fate shall never alter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then, I am once more happy:
For since none can possess her I am pleas'd
With my own choice, and will desire no more.
For multiplying wishes is a curse
That keep the mind still painfully awake:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You care and loyalty have this day oblig'd me;
But how to be acknowledging I know not,
Unless you give the means.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I was in hope your Majesty had forgot me; therefore if you please, Madam, I onely beg a pardon for having taken up armes once to day against you; for I have a foolish kind of Conscience, which I wish many of your Subjects had, that will not let me ask a recompence for my loyalty, when I know I have been a Rebel.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your modesty shall not serve the turn; Ask something.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Then I beg, Madam, you will command Florimell never to be friends with me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Ask again; I grant that without the Queen: But why are you affraid on't?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Because I am sure as soon as ever you are, you'l marry me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Do you fear it?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, 'twill come with a fear.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: If you do, I will not stick with you for an Oath.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I require no Oath till we come to Church; and then after the Priest, I hope; for I find it will be my destiny to marry thee.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: If ever I say word after the black Gentleman for thee Celadonâ€”

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Then I hope you'l give me leave to bestow a faithful heart elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I but if you would have one you must be speak it, for I am sure you have none ready made.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What say you, shall I marry Flavia?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No, she'll be too cunning for you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What say you to Olinda then? she's tall, and fair, and bonny.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: And foolish, and apish, and fickle.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: But Sabina, there's pretty, and young, and loving, and innocent.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: And dwarfish, and childish, and fond, and flippant: if you marry her Sister you will get May-poles, and if you marry her you will get Fayries to dance about them.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Nay then the case is clear, Florimell; if you take 'em all from me, 'tis because you reserve me for your self.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But this Marriage is such a Bugbear to me; much might be if we could invent but any way to mak it easie.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Some foolish people have made it uneasie, by drawing the knot faster then they need; but we that are wiser will loosen it a little.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed, there's some difference betwixt a Girdle and an Halter.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: As for the first year according to the laudable custome of new married people, we shall follow one another up into Chambers, and down into Gardens, and think we shall never have enough of one another.â€”So far 'tis pleasant enough I hope.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But after that, when we begin to live like Husband and Wife, and never come near one anotherâ€”what then Sir?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Why then our onely happiness must be to have one mind, and one will, Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: One mind if thou wilt, but prithee let us have two wills; for I find one will be little enough for me alone: But how if those wills should meet and clash, Celadon?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I warrant thee for that: Husbands and Wives keep their wills far enough asunder for ever meeting: one thing let us be sure to agree on, that is, never to be jealous.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: No; but e'en love one another as long as we can; and confess the truth when we can love no longer.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: When I have been at play, you shall never ask me what money I have lost.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: When I have been abroad you shall never enquire who treated me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Item, I will have the liberty to sleep all night, without your interrupting my repose for any evil design whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Item, Then you shall bid me good night before you sleep.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Provided always, that whatever liberties we take with other people, we continue very honest to one another.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: As far as will consist with a pleasant life.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Lastly, Whereas the names of Husband and Wife hold forth nothing, but clashing and cloying, and dulness and faintness in their signification; they shall be abolish'd for ever betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: And instead of those, we will be married by the more agreeable names of Mistress and Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: None of my priviledges to be infring'd by thee Florimell, under the penalty of a month of Fasting-nights.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: None of my priviledges to be infring'd by thee Celadon, under the penalty of Cuckoldom.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Well, if it be my fortune to be made a Cuckold, I had rather thou shouldst make me one then any one in Sicily: and for my comfort I shall have thee oftner then any of thy servants.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Laye now, is not such a marriage as good as wenching, Celadon?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This is very good, but not so good, Florimell.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now set me forward to th' Assembly.
You promise Cousin your consent?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: But most unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Philocles, I must beg your voice too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Most joyfully I give it.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Madam, but one word more; since you are so resolv'd,
That you may see, bold as my passion was,
'Twas onely for your person, not your Crown;
I swear no second love
Shall violate the flame I had for you,
But in strict imitation of your Oath
I vow a single life.

sp.speaker: Qu. to Asteria.]
sp.l: Now, my Asteria, my joys are full;
The pow'rs above that see
The innocent love I bear to Philocles,
Have giv'n its due reward; for by this means
The right of Lysimantes will devolve
Upon Candiope; and I shall have
This great content, to think, when I am dead
My Crown may fall on Philocles his head.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: Written by a Person of Honour.

lg.l: OUr Poet something doubtful of his Fate
Made choice of me to be his Advocate,
Relying on my Knowledg in the Laws,
And I as boldly undertook the Cause.
I left my Client yonder in a rant
Against the envious, and the ignorant,
Who are, he sayes, his onely Enemies:
But he contemns their malice, and defies
The sharpest of his Censurers to say
Where there is one gross fault in all his Play.
The language is so fitted for each part,
The Plot according to the Rules of Art;
And twenty other things he bid me tell you,
But I cry'd, e'en go do't your self for Nelly.
Reason, with Judges, urg'd in the defence
Of those they would condemn, is insolence;
I therefore wave the merits of his Play,
And think it fit to plead this safer way.
If, when too many in the purchase share
Robbing's not worth the danger nor the care;
The men of business must, in Policy,
Cherish a little harmless Poetry;
All wit wou'd else grow up to Knavery.
Wit is a Bird of Musick, or of Prey.
Mounting she strikes at all things in her way;
But if this Birdlime once but touch her wings,
On the next bush she sits her down, and sings.
I have but one word more; tell me I pray
What you will get by damning of our Play?
A whipt Fanatick who does not recant
Is by his Brethren call'd a suffring Saint;
And by your hands shou'd this poor Poet die
Before he does renounce his Poetry,
His death must needs confirm the Party more
Then all his scribling life could do before.
Where so much zeal does in a Sect appear,
'Tis to no purpose, 'faith, to be severe.
But 'tother day I heard this rhyming Fop
Say Criticks were the Whips, and he the Top;
For, as a Top spins best the more you baste her,
So every lash you give, he writes the faster.
